channel.title: NPR Programs: Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Trump pardons Rudy Giuliani, others who tried to overturn the 2020 election
item.description: President Trump has issued pardons for 77 people, including his former attorney Rudy Giuliani and former chief of staff Mark Meadows, who backed his effort to subvert the 2020 election.
item.content:encoded: President Trump has issued pardons for 77 people, including his former attorney Rudy Giuliani and former chief of staff Mark Meadows, who backed his effort to subvert the 2020 election.
item.dc:creator: Miles Parks

item.title: Senate moves toward reopening government as moderate Democrats join GOP for vote
item.description: Senate lawmakers voted late Sunday on a measure that would reopen the government, with enough moderate Democrats joining Republicans to support the initial vote.
item.content:encoded: Senate lawmakers voted late Sunday on a measure that would reopen the government, with enough moderate Democrats joining Republicans to support the initial vote.
item.dc:creator: Claudia Grisales

item.title: Sen. Catherine Cortez Masto talks about efforts to end the government shutdown
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Democratic Sen. Catherine Cortez Masto of Nevada about the latest efforts in the Senate to end the longest government shutdown in U.S. history.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Democratic Sen. Catherine Cortez Masto of Nevada about the latest efforts in the Senate to end the longest government shutdown in U.S. history.
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: Trump issued pardons to allies linked to the 2020 election efforts. What that means
item.description: President Trump pardoned a long list of political allies accused of trying to overturn the 2020 election. Stanford Law School professor Bernadette Meyler talks about the pardons and what they mean.
item.content:encoded: President Trump pardoned a long list of political allies accused of trying to overturn the 2020 election. Stanford Law School professor Bernadette Meyler talks about the pardons and what they mean.
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Senate takes the first step toward ending the government shutdown, SNAP benefits remain caught in the chaos of the shutdown and legal battles, COP30 begins Monday, but the U.S. won't be there.
item.content:encoded: Senate takes the first step toward ending the government shutdown, SNAP benefits remain caught in the chaos of the shutdown and legal battles, COP30 begins Monday, but the U.S. won't be there.
item.dc:creator: Leila Fadel

item.title: 'Juan Gabriel' explores the life and musical legacy of the beloved Mexican singer
item.description: NPR's A Martínez speaks with María José Cuevas, who directed "Juan Gabriel: I Must, I Can, I Will," a docuseries about the beloved Mexican singer-songwriter.
item.content:encoded: NPR's A Martínez speaks with María José Cuevas, who directed "Juan Gabriel: I Must, I Can, I Will," a docuseries about the beloved Mexican singer-songwriter.
item.dc:creator: A Martínez

item.title: SNAP recipients feel whiplash as shutdown deal uncertainty clouds food aid
item.description: As lawmakers debate a shutdown deal, SNAP recipients continue to face confusion and delays, with food aid caught in uncertainty and legal wrangling since funds ran out.
item.content:encoded: As lawmakers debate a shutdown deal, SNAP recipients continue to face confusion and delays, with food aid caught in uncertainty and legal wrangling since funds ran out.
item.dc:creator: Tovia Smith

item.title: Syrian president to meet with President Trump Monday
item.description: This time last year, Ahmed al-Sharaa [[ahk-mahd al-SHAH-raa]] had a $10 million U.S. bounty on his head. He is now Syria's president and will meet with President Trump at the White House Monday.
item.content:encoded: This time last year, Ahmed al-Sharaa [[ahk-mahd al-SHAH-raa]] had a $10 million U.S. bounty on his head. He is now Syria's president and will meet with President Trump at the White House Monday.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf

item.title: Typhoon Fung-wong batters the Philippines, killing 2 and displacing 1.4 million
item.description: Typhoon Fung-wong slammed the Philippines Monday, killing two and displacing over 1 million people. NPR's Leila Fadel speaks to the World Food Programme's Regis Chapman about the aid being provided.
item.content:encoded: Typhoon Fung-wong slammed the Philippines Monday, killing two and displacing over 1 million people. NPR's Leila Fadel speaks to the World Food Programme's Regis Chapman about the aid being provided.
item.dc:creator: Leila Fadel

item.title: 100-year-old veteran remembers the raising of the flag after the Battle of Iwo Jima
item.description: A 100-year-old veteran who survived the Battle of Iwo Jima recounts his experience and the freedom he's enjoyed since the Allies won World War II.
item.content:encoded: A 100-year-old veteran who survived the Battle of Iwo Jima recounts his experience and the freedom he's enjoyed since the Allies won World War II.
item.dc:creator: Bente Birkeland
